section.name: genesis aspects
section.p: A number of genesis features are implemented using aspects. AOP usage makes it possible to extend these features in a significant way with no need to change business or UI code. This documentation section aim is to describe these aspects so that advanced users can understand and customize their behaviour. In order to fully understand this section, AOP, AspectWerkz, EJB and Thinlet knowledge is required.

section.name: Determining remotable and transactional methods
section.p: Interface CommandResolver, contained in package net.java.dev.genesis.aspect, is used to determine whether a method is remotable or transactional or not. Below, it is possible to see the relevant code section for the interface definition:

Aspect CommandInvocationAspect, defined in the same package as the interface, has a inner class that implements this interface, CommandResolverImpl, that decides whether a method is remotable/transactional or not if it is annotated with @Remotable or @Transactional or if the class containing the method implements Query or Transaction, deprecated interfaces from genesis 0.1.

If the value for the aspect parameter named useFastMode is true - that is its default value -, any method will be considered remotable, since in the provided aop.xml configuration only remotable or transactional methods are intercepted by the execution pointcut. This implementation is introduced in classes selected by the pointcut named commandResolverIntroduction.

If it is necessary to determine if a method is remotable or transactional using a different strategy - based on an external xml definition instead of using annotation, for example -, one just have to provide a custom implementation of CommandResolver that takes this decision using this strategy and introduce it into business classes.

section.name: Executing remotable and transactional methods
section.p: Remotable and transactional method execution is intercepted by an aspect so that instances can be transfered (or not, as we'll see soon) to the server and an appropriate transactional context can be used for executing the original call. Besides that, dependency injection is done before execuction.
Two components implement that: an aspect and a net.java.dev.genesis.command.TransactionalInjector implementation. Interface TransactionalInjector is defined as follows:
The interface implementation is used by aspects in a well defined manner, as follow:

ol.li: Right after instantiation, method init(Object) is called with a context object as a parameter. This context object is execution mode specific - local, in an EJB environment etc. - and it allows the newly created instance to read user defined configurations.

The beforeInvocation(Object,boolean) method is invoked before executing any remotable or transactional method. Its arguments are the object in which the method will be called and the transactional status for the call. At this moment eventual dependencies should be injected into the instance and that a transaction should be started if necessary.
afterInvocation() is only invoked when method execution happens with no errors, i.e., when no exception is thrown. It's when a transaction should be commited.

onException(Exception) gets called if an exception if thrown during beforeInvocation(Object,boolean) method or during execution of the remotable/transactional method. That's the moment to rollback the transaction.
onFinally() is always called and should release any resources allocated during execution.

section.p: Each TransactionalInjector instance will be used by just one Thread.

By using custom aspects and implementations of TransactionalInjector it is possible to completely change the way transactions are executed and perform any type of dependency injection in business components. Three powerful execution modes are provided with genesis and explained below.

subsection.name: Local execution
subsection.p: Local execution is performed by the LocalCommandExecutionAspect aspect. Basically, this aspect delegates most of the work to a TransactionalInjector implementation, as the following code snippet proves:

Pointcut localCommandExecution is used to define which method execution should be intercepted by advice commandExecution(JoinPoint). A TransactionalInjector implementation can be configured by setting the aspect parameter transactionalInjector to the class name. The context object passed as an argument to init(Object) will be the CrossCuttingInfo instance the aspect holds.

Class HibernateTransactionalInjector, that is also contained in net.java.dev.genesis.aspect is an appropriate TransactionalInjector implementation for this scenario. It introduces a Hibernate session in classes that implement net.java.dev.genesis.command.hibernate.HibernateCommand and it controls transactions using resources provided by the Hibernate session itself. Unless the preLoadSessionFactory parameter is false, the Hibernate SessionFactory object will be instantiated when the first @Remotable or @Transactional method call is made, what usually happens at startup.

subsection.name: Remote EJB execution
subsection.p: Another execution possibility bundled with genesis is executing the call inside a Stateless Session Bean, taking advantage of container managed transactions (CMT). Aspect EJBCommandExecutionAspect does that by invoking executeTransaction(Object,String,String[],Object[]) and executeQuery(Object,String,String[],Object[]) in the EJB instance whose remote interface is net.java.dev.genesis.ejb.CommandExecutor. Argument values for both methods are the instance for which a method will be invoked, method name, class names for method signature and values used in the original invocation.

Advice commandExecution(JoinPoint) will actually do a remote invocation to the Session Bean instance. Pointcut named ejbCommandExecution will be used to select which method execution should be performed remotely. Aspect parameter named jndiName contains the JNDI address for the EJB home instance, while the boolean parameter retryOnNoSuchObject indicates whether execution should be retried (just once more) when a java.rmi.NoSuchObjectException is thrown (that may happen if the application server is restarted).

Since method execution takes place in a Session Bean instance, the TransactionalInjector implementation resides on the server, and it can be specified as the value for an env-entry named TransactionalInjector. The context object passed as an argument to init(Object), is the instance of SessionContext the Session Bean instance holds.

Implementation net.java.dev.genesis.ejb.hibernate.EJBHibernateTransactionalInjector provided by genesis is the appropriate one for this configuration. During its init(Object) method execution, a Hibernate SessionFactory implementation is retrived from the JNDI adress specified as a value for env-entry HibernateFactoryAddress. The transaction mechanism used by this implementation is JTA, since only methods that use CMT are involved in execution. Rollback will be performed, if necessary, by calling setRollbackOnly() in the SessionContext instance.

subsection.name: Local EJB execution
subsection.p: Executing the method inside a Stateless Session Bean instance with CMT through the EJB local interface might be a better option in some environments, such as web applications, for example. The aspect named LocalEJBCommandExecutionAspect invokes the net.java.dev.genesis.ejb.CommandExecutor instance using the exposed local interface and its behaviour is basically the same as the behaviour of the previously aspect mentioned, EJBCommandExecutionAspect, except for the following things:

ul.li: The name of the execution pointcut is localEjbCommandExecution
Only the parameter named jndiName is meaningful, since there is no remote communication with the server

section.name: Executing dynamic searches
section.p: Dynamic searches, i.e., classes that have a Criteria instance injected on them and have setters invoked for non-empty properties, are executed by the net.java.dev.genesis.aspect.CriteriaCommandExecutionAspect aspect.
Every class intercepted by this aspect must implement net.java.dev.genesis.command.hibernate.CriteriaResolver, shown below:

Method setPropertiesMap(Map) will be invoked on the client side passing only data that will be used for performing the search. Usually this method will be invoked indirectly by calling the auxiliary method fillCriteria(HibernateCriteria,Object) contained in net.java.dev.genesis.helpers.CriteriaPropertyHelper.

Pointcut named criteriaResolverIntroduction defines which classes will have an implementation of this interface called CriteriaResolverImpl introduced into them. This is static inner class of the aspect. This implementation uses a member variable whose type is java.util.Map to keep and expose properties.

Pointcut named criteriaCommandExecution defines which methods will be intercepted by the commandExecution(JoinPoint) advice. This method relies on information returned by getPropertiesMap() in CriteriaResolver to determine which properties will be used for the search, together with the method signature and argument values to instantiate net.java.dev.genesis.command.hibernate.CriteriaCommandExecutor. Method execute() will be called on the new instance. Since this method is annotated as @Remotable, it will be intercepted for remote execution. This method initializes a Criteria instance (when the name of a Hibernate mapped class is configured for the annotation), injects it into the instance, invokes setters for search criteria and invokes the search method.

section.name: Limiting method execution time
section.p: Aspect TimeoutAspect allows controlling how long a method takes to execute; if the execution times out, a net.java.dev.genesis.exception.TimeoutException will be thrown.

The time limit is configured by the aspect parameter named timeout. Pointcut named timeout selects methods whose execution will be intercepted by advice timeoutAdvice(JoinPoint). This advice executes the intercepted method in a new thread and waits for its completion for timeout seconds. Any exception that could be normally thrown by the intercepted method is thrown back to the caller.

The keepThreadInstance parameter defines whether genesis should reuse the thread which controls the execution timeout of a method. In case this parameter is set to true, the aspect will create and maintain a single thread and therefore all next intercepted methods executions will reuse the same thread. This way the application perfomance will be increased.

However in case the application needs quite a few threads to run, this parameter (if set to true) will keep a lot of children threads in memory that might consume system resources - this way, in this particular case, it is recommended setting this parameter to false.

section.name: Changing mouse cursor during event handling
section.p: In order to allow a user to realize a time consuming operation is being performed, aspect WaitCursorAspect changes the mouse cursor to a wait cursor during a UI event handling method.

Pointcut named waitCursorExecution specify which methods perform event handling and must be intercepted by the advice named waitCursorExecution(JoinPoint). This advice saves the current cursor, changes it to a wait cursor and then restore the original cursor when event handling is done. It is expected that the intercepted methods belong to a java.awt.Component instance, since this class is the one that defines methods for getting and setting the current cursor.

section.name: Instantiating metadata
section.p: All form to view binding is based on metadata exposed by both sides. This metadata model can be found at net.java.dev.genesis.ui.metadata for forms and views. In this package, there are interfaces - FormMetadataFactory and ViewMetadataFactory -, that need to be implemented by classes responsible for returning metadata. Below there is a transcription of relevant code snippets for both of them:

Aspects FormMetadataFactoryAspect and ViewMetadataFactoryAspect define implementations of these interfaces that use annotation for building metadata. The implementations are called AspectFormMetadataFactory and AspectViewMetadataFactory and they are static inner classes of the aspects. Classes that need to have these implementations introduced into them are selected by pointcuts named formMetadataFactoryIntroduction and viewMetadataFactoryIntroduction. To override the way metadata is created - by using an external xml definition, for example - one just have to introduce different interface implementations in forms and views.
The ThinletMetadataFactory class and its related classes have been replaced starting from relase 2.1 by the ViewMetadataFactory class family and they will be removed in a future genesis release.

section.name: Instantiating the form controller
section.p: Updating the internal state of a form and firing events related to changes is performed by a net.java.dev.genesis.ui.controller.FormController implementation. The FormController instance is obtained by using the net.java.dev.genesis.ui.controller.FormControllerFactory interface. Its definition is:

The FormControllerFactoryAspect aspect defines an implementation of this interface as a static inner class, AspectFormControllerFactory, that always return a net.java.dev.genesis.ui.controller.DefaultFormController instance. Classes that need to have this implementation introduced into them are selected by the pointcut named formControllerFactoryIntroduction.

section.name: Configuration reference
section.p: There are below a few useful tables for advanced developers and also a default configuration that should be enough for most situations.

Configures how the name for the method to be executed will be obtained from the MethodJoinPoint instance. It should be true for local execution modes.

Indicates whether the method should be called again if a java.rmi.NoSuchObjectException occurs

A JNDI address from where a net.java.dev.genesis.ejb.CommandExecutorLocalHome instance can be obtained
Maximum amount of milliseconds a method execution can take
Indicates whether the timeout controlling thread should be kept and reused by all intercepted methods

subsection.name: Named pointcuts
subsection.p: Named pointcuts will only be available when the annotated jar is used and, under these conditions, attributing values for them is mandatory if the aspect that defines them is configured.

subsection.name: Sample aop.xml configuration
subsection.p: useradmin sample remote-aop.xml configuration is shown below. It might be necessary to adjust it as needed by a project, but we believe this configuration will be enough for most cases.
subsection.source:
<!DOCTYPE aspectwerkz PUBLIC "-//AspectWerkz//DTD 1.0//EN" "http://aspectwerkz.codehaus.org/dtd/aspectwerkz_1_0.dtd"> <aspectwerkz> <system id="useradmin" base-package="net.java.dev.genesis.aspect"> <!-- helpers pointcuts --> <pointcut name="executeCommand" expression="execution(@Remotable * ...*(..)) OR execution(@Transactional * ...*(..))" /> <pointcut name="form" expression="within(@Form ..)" />
<!-- genesis pointcuts --> <pointcut name="formMetadataFactoryIntroduction" expression="form" /> <pointcut name="formControllerFactoryIntroduction" expression="form" /> <pointcut name="thinletMetadataFactoryIntroduction" expression="within(net.java.dev.genesis.ui.thinlet.BaseThinlet+)" /> <pointcut name="viewMetadataFactoryIntroduction" expression="thinletMetadataFactoryIntroduction OR within(@ViewHandler ..)" /> <pointcut name="criteriaResolverIntroduction" expression="within(net.java.dev.genesis.command.hibernate.HibernateCriteria+)" /> <pointcut name="commandResolverIntroduction" expression="hasmethod(@Remotable * ...*(..)) OR hasmethod(@Transactional * ...*(..))" /> <pointcut name="timeout" expression="executeCommand" /> <pointcut name="ejbCommandExecution" expression="executeCommand" /> <pointcut name="criteriaCommandExecution" expression="execution(@Criteria * net.java.dev.genesis.command.hibernate.HibernateCriteria+.*(..))" /> <pointcut name="waitCursorExecution" expression="execution(* thinlet.Thinlet.invokeImpl(..))" />
<!-- genesis aspects --> <aspect class="CommandInvocationAspect" /> <aspect class="FormMetadataFactoryAspect" /> <aspect class="FormControllerFactoryAspect" /> <aspect class="ViewMetadataFactoryAspect" /> <aspect class="TimeoutAspect"> <param name="timeout" value="60000" /> <param name="keepThreadInstance" value="true" /> </aspect> <aspect class="EJBCommandExecutionAspect"> <param name="jndiName" value="ejb/CommandExecutor"/> </aspect> <aspect class="CriteriaCommandExecutionAspect"/> <aspect class="WaitCursorAspect"/> </system> </aspectwerkz>
